items.title: This year, we are committed to bringing our neighbors home by...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

This year, we are committed to bringing our neighbors home by safely lowering jail populations and keeping our immigrant neighbors out of detention, and you can help. Collaborate with us in this year's ACLU of Colorado Lobby Day and train in defending civil liberties in our state. RSVP: https://aclu.zoom.us/…/register/tZcqce2hqjkoHNDnAUyaq-PozAA…

items.title: Mass incarceration has led to overcrowded jails and prisons, and...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

Mass incarceration has led to overcrowded jails and prisons, and the needless deaths of Michael Marshall, Marvin Booker, and countless others across Colorado. We are long overdue for serious change. Take action now and urge your legislators to support safely reducing the number of people held pretrial in Colorado jails. https://action.aclu.org/send-message/co-sb21-062

items.title: "The fact is that we have had an addiction to jails and...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

"The fact is that we have had an addiction to jails and prisons for a long time, and yet we are no safer as a result of them. So we need to find a different way," Said Denise Maes, public policy director of the ACLU of Colorado. SB62 provides a safer, more just path forward than the status quo.

Boulder has become the center of a robust debate about criminal justice reform as legislation proposed by the ACLU and introduced in the Colorado Senate has drawn criticism from local law enforcement, businesses and residents. If passed, Senate Bill 21-062 would increase law enforcement discretion t...

boulderweekly.com

Boulder could play central role in shaping state pretrial reform legislation - Boulder Weekly

Boulder has become the center of a robust debate about criminal justice reform as legislation proposed by the ACLU and introduced in the Colorado Senate has drawn criticism from local law enforcement, businesses and residents. If passed, Senate Bill 21-062 would increase law enforcement discretion t...Boulder has become the center of a robust debate about criminal justice reform as legislation proposed by the ACLU and introduced in the Colorado Senate has drawn criticism from local law enforcement, businesses and residents. If passed, Senate Bill 21-062 would increase law enforcement discretion t...

items.title: The American Bail Association’s arguments against SB62 — a...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

The American Bail Association’s arguments against SB62 — a bill aimed at safely reducing arrests, cash bail, and jail populations — is simply inaccurate fear-mongering aimed at doing one thing, and one thing only: saving a dying, cruel industry that capitalizes on poverty and ignores the presumption of innocence.

Sen. Pete Lee is still working to reform Colorado’s criminal justice system. Hoping to make COVID-driven emergency measures adopted by sheriffs across Colorado permanent, he is sponsoring Senate Bill 21-062,

csindy.com

Senate bill targets monetary bonds for some offenses

Sen. Pete Lee is still working to reform Colorado’s criminal justice system. Hoping to make COVID-driven emergency measures adopted by sheriffs across Colorado permanent, he is sponsoring Senate Bill 21-062,Sen. items.title: Get involved in this year's ACLU of Colorado Lobby Day....
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

Get involved in this year's ACLU of Colorado Lobby Day. Learn how to talk to your elected representatives about civil liberty issues in Colorado, then join us in the conversation with key legislators in the state. RSVP: https://aclu.zoom.us/…/register/tZcqce2hqjkoHNDnAUyaq-PozAA…

items.title: Locking up people for low-level crimes who pose no public threat...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

Locking up people for low-level crimes who pose no public threat has failed us from a safety perspective, a racial justice perspective and a human dignity perspective. SB21-62 is a measured approach to alleviate suffering while protecting public safety.

Much has been written by The Gazette editorial board and Gazette columnist Jimmy Sengenberger about SB21-62, a bill I am sponsoring to safely reduce arrests, cash bail and jail populations.

gazette.com

GUEST COLUMN: Protecting the public -- and presumption of innocence

Much has been written by The Gazette editorial board and Gazette columnist Jimmy Sengenberger about SB21-62, a bill I am sponsoring to safely reduce arrests, cash bail and jail populations.Much has been written by The Gazette editorial board and Gazette columnist Jimmy Sengenberger about SB21-62, a bill I am sponsoring to safely reduce arrests, cash bail and jail populations.

items.title: You can support our work to bring our neighbors home by donating...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

You can support our work to bring our neighbors home by donating all or part of your state tax refund. Use our reg. number 20023005801 to give when you file. https://refundwhatmatters.org

Donate from your state income tax refund to a Colorado charity. It’s simple, fast and puts you in charge of where your gift goes.

ACLU of ColoradoRocky Mountain Women's Film

Our FREE Film in the Community virtual screening is going on now, and it's not too late to watch #RMWFilmAlum THE FIGHT. Then join us Thursday, March 25 at 7 pm... for a special conversation with Deborah Richardson, Executive Director of ACLU of Colorado.

Register and find out more: https://rmwfilm.org/event-calendar/fic-the-fight/

items.title: We are heartbroken over the loss of ten lives during the...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

We are heartbroken over the loss of ten lives during the horrific attack in Boulder yesterday. Our deepest sympathies go out to those whose loved ones lost their lives, were injured, or were otherwise impacted by this tragedy.

As we work toward concrete avenues for change, we are committed to supporting the victims and their loved ones, and helping our fellow Coloradans work to heal the scars that too many tragedies like this one have left on our state.

Rest in peace, neighbo...rs.

Denny Stong, 20
Neven Stanisic, 23
Rikki Olds, 25
Tralona Bartkowiak, 49
Suzanne Fountain, 59
Teri Leiker, 51
Officer Eric Talley, 51
Kevin Mahoney, 61
Lynn Murray, 62
Jody Waters, 65

Our full statement: https://aclu-co.org/aclu-of-colorado-statement-on-boulder-…/

When you give a portion of your state income tax refund, you make a direct impact to end wealth-based pretrial incarceration. Use our reg. number 20023005801. https://refundwhatmatters.org

Donate from your state income tax refund to a Colorado charity. It’s simple, fast and puts you in charge of where your gift goes.

items.title: Jackson Maes died by suicide in jail. His crime? Missing a court...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

Jackson Maes died by suicide in jail. His crime? Missing a court date for a traffic ticket. After making comments about wanting to kill himself deputies did not put him on suicide watch or check on him for over eight hours. A justice system that requires money in exchange for freedom can ultimately cost lives.

Jackson Maes, 27, died by suicide about 10:30 p.m. Nov. 16, 2019, in the Saguache County jail. Deputies did not find his body until 7 a.m. the following day, according to sheriff’s office doc…

denverpost.com

Colorado jail deputies failed to check on inmate after he made suicidal comments. They didn’t find his body for 8 hours.

Jackson Maes, 27, died by suicide about 10:30 p.m. Nov. 16, 2019, in the Saguache County jail. Deputies did not find his body until 7 a.m. the following day, according to sheriff’s office doc…Jackson Maes, 27, died by suicide about 10:30 p.m. Nov. 16, 2019, in the Saguache County jail. Deputies did not find his body until 7 a.m. the following day, according to sheriff’s office doc…

items.title: Children with disabilities and children of color are...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

Children with disabilities and children of color are disproportionately targeted by School Resource Officers to be punished and arrested. The presence of SROs in schools only continues to bolster the school-to-prison pipeline. Colorado needs real systemic change.

Critics of the state police and justice systems say the so-called “pipeline from schools to prisons” for minorities and children with disabilities can be changed by state lawmakers

sentinelcolorado.com

INVISIBLE JUSTICE: State lawmakers look to prevent children with ‘invisible’ disabilities from being channeled into the justice system - Sentinel Colorado

Critics of the state police and justice systems say the so-called “pipeline from schools to prisons” for minorities and children with disabilities can be changed by state lawmakersCritics of the state police and justice systems say the so-called “pipeline from schools to prisons” for minorities and children with disabilities can be changed by state lawmakers

ACLU of Colorado

Your state income tax refund can help us protect and extend civil rights and liberties. When you file, look for the prompt to Donate to a Colorado Nonprofit and use our reg. number 20023005801. Learn about how you can give when you file: https://refundwhatmatters.org

Donate from your state income tax refund to a Colorado charity. It’s simple, fast and puts you in charge of where your gift goes.

items.title: Counselors, Not Cops: Heidi’s son J.L. was labeled as a...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

Counselors, Not Cops: Heidi’s son J.L. was labeled as a problem child in preschool. Instead of receiving help and understanding for his anxiety and sensory issues, he was punished and restrained multiple times by SROs. The stigma of constant SRO calls and suspensions instead of accommodations made J.L. feel worse about himself than ever. No child should ever feel worthless — especially in school. Read more here: https://aclu-co.org/heidi-laursen-and-her-son-j-l/

items.title: A child suffers from persisting trauma and fear because adults...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

A child suffers from persisting trauma and fear because adults failed him. School officials and SROs neglected his safety and needs, creating a situation where an 11-year-old child with autism was targeted and traumatized. It didn’t have to be this way. https://www.washingtonpost.com/…/school-police-autism-colo…/

“Stop! Stop! You’re hurting me!” the boy exclaimed to the officers. “Don’t you know what the word ‘stop’ means?”

washingtonpost.com

An 11-year-old with autism was arrested for scratching a classmate with a pencil, lawsuit says

“Stop! Stop! You’re hurting me!” the boy exclaimed to the officers. “Don’t you know what the word ‘stop’ means?”“Stop! Stop! You’re hurting me!” the boy exclaimed to the officers. “Don’t you know what the word ‘stop’ means?”

items.title: "In this particular case, the family would not have been...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

"In this particular case, the family would not have been asked to post a $25,000 bond to bring home their eleven-year-old child," notes Elise Logemann, the ACLU of Colorado's juvenile-justice policy counsel. "Had this family not had the ability to post the bond, which many families do not, the child — who has autism — might have remained behind bars in a secure juvenile facility."

https://www.westword.com/…/shocking-video-of-autistic-child…

The child banged his head in a patrol car for hours.

westword.com

Disturbing Video of Autistic Child Handcuffing: Lawsuit and More

The child banged his head in a patrol car for hours.The child banged his head in a patrol car for hours.

items.title: “I felt like they were trying to put him in the system,”...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

“I felt like they were trying to put him in the system,” Shandie said about J.J., her 16-year-old son who has autism. “Why not call me first? I could’ve helped de-escalate the situation.” After many times being kicked off of school grounds at random, J.J. was ticketed for harassment after making a teacher feel "uncomfortable." Shandie was never made aware of the situation by the school. Instead, she would later receive a call from a police officer. Read more about Shandie and J.J.'s story: https://aclu-co.org/shandie-harris-and-her-son-j-j/

items.title: Michelle Hanson always wanted her kids to go to their...
items.content_html:
ACLU of Colorado

Michelle Hanson always wanted her kids to go to their neighborhood schools. That was until the day her 11-year-old son A.V., who has autism, ended up handcuffed in the back of a police car for hours, sobbing, injured, and traumatized when school resource officers decided to intervene in a situation they didn't understand and were not equipped to handle. Read more about Michelle and A.V.'s story: https://aclu-co.org/michelle-hanson-and-her-son-a-v/
